question: Question_12_(a)
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problems}. In questions 4â12, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work}. If a box is provided, write
your final answer there. \textbf{Unless otherwise indicated,
simplification of numerical answers is required in these questions}.

Prove that $\displaystyle \int_2^\infty \frac{x+\sin x}{1+x^2} \ dx$
diverges.
sols:
Since this integral can be solved directly, we try the comparison test
instead to prove divergence. Notice that for large $\displaystyle x$,
the integrand behaves like $\displaystyle 1/x$. Since
$\int_2^\infty 1/x\ dx$ diverges, it will be our goal to show that our
integrand is larger than a constant times $\displaystyle 1/x$.

First, since $\displaystyle \sin x \geq -1$, we have

\begin{align*}\displaystyle 
\frac{x+\sin x}{1+x^2} \geq \frac{x-1}{1+x^2}\end{align*}

Now, for $\displaystyle x \geq 2$, we have

\begin{align*}\displaystyle 
\frac{x-1}{1+x^2} \geq \frac{1}{3x}\end{align*}

To prove this, notice if $\displaystyle x \geq 2$, then

\begin{align*} 
x(2x-3) & \geq 2 \cdot 1 \geq 1 \\
3x^2-3x & \geq x^2 + 1 \\
\frac{x-1}{1+x^2} & \geq \frac{1}{3x}\end{align*}

where in the second line we added $\displaystyle x^2$ to both sides, and
in the third line we divided by $\displaystyle (3x)(1+x^2) > 0$.

Now, since

\begin{align*}\displaystyle 
\int_2^\infty \frac{1}{3x} \ dx = \frac{1}{3} \int_2^\infty \frac{1}{x} \ dx\end{align*}

diverges by \emph{p}-test, we have that

\begin{align*}
\int_2^\infty \frac{x+\sin x}{1+x^2} \ dx &\geq \int_2^\infty \frac{x-1}{1+x^2} \ dx \\
&\geq \int_2^\infty \frac1{3x}\ dx \\ 
&= \frac{1}{3} \int_2^\infty \frac{1}{x} \ dx > \infty\end{align*}

and hence the original integral diverges by the Comparison Test, as
required.
hints:
Intuition should say that the numerator looks like \emph{x} and the
denominator is like $x^{2}$ and so this function should look like the
inverse of \emph{x} which should diverge. If you're trying to prove it
diverges, you don't need to find the exact antiderivative; there are
other ways of proving divergence of integrals.
What does the integrand look like for large $\displaystyle x$?
